Create a 2000 words article conversational article and Rephrase this with 100% no plagiarism and unique Dell plans to lay off roughly 5% of its workforce, the company said in a regulatory filing Monday, in the latest example of tech companies cutting costs in an uncertain economic climate.

Dell has about 133,000 employees, the company told CNN. At that level, the 5% cut would represent more than 6,500 employees.

Dell is to lay off about 6,650 workers because of the decline in demand for personal computers.

The job cuts are expected to affect about 5% of its global workforce.

The company faced tough market conditions with an uncertain future and its previous cost-cutting measures were no longer enough, co-chief operating officer Jeff Clarke wrote in a memo.

Dell, based in Round Rock, Texas, announced similar lay-offs in 2020, after the pandemic hit.

The computing giant cited the "challenging global economic environment" for the cuts. In a letter to employees, Jeff Clarke, Dell's vice chairman, said steps the company has already taken - such as restrictions on employee travel and a pause on external hiring - are insufficient.

"What we know is market conditions continue to erode with an uncertain future," Clarke told employees. "The steps we've taken to stay ahead of downturn impacts -- which enabled several strong quarters in a row -- are no longer enough. We now have to make additional decisions to prepare for the road ahead."

The move comes as layoffs continue to spread throughout the tech industry. Amazon, Microsoft, Google and others have each announced plans to cut thousands of workers as the companies adapt to shifting pandemic demand and fears of a looming recession.

Dell has also been grappling with reduced demand for personal computers.

Consulting firm Gartner said last month that worldwide PC shipments fell more than 28% in the fourth quarter of 2022 compared to the same period the prior year. This marked the largest quarterly shipment decline since Gartner began tracking the PC market in the mid-90s.

Dell, in particular, saw a 37% decline in PC vendor unit shipments during the final three months of 2022 compared to the year prior, according to Gartner.

Dell is to lay off about 6,650 workers because of the decline in demand for personal computers.

The job cuts are expected to affect about 5% of its global workforce.

The company faced tough market conditions with an uncertain future and its previous cost-cutting measures were no longer enough, co-chief operating officer Jeff Clarke wrote in a memo.

Dell, based in Round Rock, Texas, announced similar lay-offs in 2020, after the pandemic hit.
The latest department reorganisations and job cuts were an opportunity to drive efficiency, a company representative said.

"We continuously evaluate operations to ensure the right structure is in place to provide the best value and support to partners and customers.

"This is part of our regular course of business," a Dell spokesperson told the BBC.
Lay-offs in the US hit a more than two-year high in January, as the technology industry, once a reliable source of employment, cut jobs at the second-highest pace on record - to brace for a possible recession, a report showed on Thursday.

Companies including Google, Amazon and Meta are now grappling with how to balance cost-cutting measures with the need to remain competitive, as consumer and corporate spending shrinks amid high inflation and rising interest rates, after the pandemic.

Chief executive Mark Zuckerberg said recent job cuts had been "the most difficult changes we've made in Meta's history", while Twitter cut about half its staff after multi-billionaire Elon Musk took control, in October.

In a recent announcement, Dell, the Texas-based computer technology company, has revealed that it plans to lay off approximately 5% of its workforce due to declining demand for personal computers. The job cuts will affect about 6,650 employees globally, as the company grapples with tough market conditions and an uncertain future. This move follows similar layoffs in 2020, when the pandemic hit, and marks the latest example of tech companies cutting costs in an effort to adapt to shifting pandemic demand and fears of a looming recession.

Jeff Clarke, Dell's co-chief operating officer, wrote in a memo to employees that the company's previous cost-cutting measures, such as restrictions on employee travel and a pause on external hiring, were no longer sufficient to address the challenging global economic environment. "What we know is market conditions continue to erode with an uncertain future," Clarke told employees. "The steps we've taken to stay ahead of downturn impacts -- which enabled several strong quarters in a row -- are no longer enough. We now have to make additional decisions to prepare for the road ahead."

Dell, which currently employs about 133,000 workers, has seen a decline in demand for personal computers, with worldwide PC shipments falling more than 28% in the fourth quarter of 2022 compared to the same period the prior year, according to consulting firm Gartner. Dell, in particular, saw a 37% decline in PC vendor unit shipments during the final three months of 2022 compared to the year prior, according to the same source.

The layoffs at Dell come as tech companies such as Amazon, Microsoft, and Google also announce plans to cut thousands of workers. With the pandemic and global economic uncertainty continuing to impact consumer and corporate spending, companies in the tech industry are grappling with the need to balance cost-cutting measures with remaining competitive. Layoffs in the US have hit a more than two-year high in January, with the technology industry, once a reliable source of employment, cutting jobs at the second-highest pace on record.

Despite the job cuts, a representative for Dell said that the latest department reorganizations and job cuts were an opportunity to drive efficiency and that the company continuously evaluates operations to ensure the right structure is in place to provide the best value and support to partners and customers. "This is part of our regular course of business," the Dell spokesperson told the BBC.

The challenge for Dell and other tech companies will be to continue to adapt and evolve in a rapidly changing market while finding ways to maintain profitability and keep their employees engaged and motivated. As the economic landscape continues to shift, it remains to be seen how these companies will fare in the months and years to come.

The recent wave of layoffs in the tech industry has been attributed to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and the subsequent economic uncertainty that has ensued. With global supply chains disrupted, consumer spending dwindling, and the shift towards remote work, companies have had to re-evaluate their operations and make tough decisions to cut costs.

Dell, like many other companies, has not been immune to these challenges. As the demand for personal computers declined, the company found itself with excess capacity and had to make the difficult decision to cut its workforce.

The layoffs will affect about 5% of Dell's global workforce, or roughly 6,650 employees. While the decision was a difficult one, Dell's co-chief operating officer Jeff Clarke explained in a memo that the company had to make additional cost-cutting measures to prepare for the future.

"What we know is market conditions continue to erode with an uncertain future," Clarke wrote. "The steps we've taken to stay ahead of downturn impacts -- which enabled several strong quarters in a row -- are no longer enough. We now have to make additional decisions to prepare for the road ahead."

Dell's recent layoffs are not the first for the company. In 2020, the company also announced similar job cuts after the pandemic hit. However, the decline in demand for personal computers has continued, and the company had to take further steps to adjust to the changing market conditions.

The layoffs come as the tech industry as a whole is facing tough times. Companies like Amazon, Microsoft, and Google have also announced plans to cut thousands of workers as they adapt to shifting pandemic demand and fears of a looming recession.

While the layoffs are certainly tough for those affected, Dell has said that it's part of the company's regular course of business to evaluate operations and make adjustments where necessary.

"We continuously evaluate operations to ensure the right structure is in place to provide the best value and support to partners and customers," a Dell spokesperson told the BBC. "This is part of our regular course of business."

The spokesperson also emphasized that the recent department reorganizations and job cuts were an opportunity to drive efficiency and create a leaner, more agile company that can better serve its customers.

In the end, the decision to cut jobs is never an easy one. However, for many companies in the tech industry, it has become a necessary step to remain competitive and weather the economic uncertainty that lies ahead. As we move forward, it will be interesting to see how companies like Dell continue to adapt and navigate the challenges of an ever-changing market.
